ron tsuba has often 
been changed (passively or actively), it depends on th=
e light used to view or photograph 
and depends very much on the perception=
 of the observer.  I would suggest concentrating

ing Kanayama tsuba before considering color.

k that early Kanayama do not tend to show a reddish tone.  Not 
all Momoyam=
a ones are reddish in my experience, but some are.  So, the observation is =

ate iron color use direct but not dazzling sunlight.

>=

 qualitative aspects of its iron.  However, he tends not to elaborate

on this, and since the images are virtually entirely in black and

e in the two well-known English language texts on sukashi tsuba,

 A few times he does note that Momoyama Kanayama tsuba tend

reddish cast to them (as well as being smaller) when

ama guards of earlier times.  I was just wondering if

ensus among those of you who have much experience with

sistent as to be understood as definitive of
